Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Novel probes to quantify the relative importance of ion and particle uptake when assessing nanoparticle bioavailability

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1508931
Lead, Jamie

Nanoparticles may be an important environmental contaminant because their use leads to discharge into the environment and many of them have been shown to be toxic. In order to be toxic, nanoparticles must enter an organism such as a bacterium or a fish. This "bioavailability" is governed by the uptake from the environment, loss from the organism and other processes. However, it is not known if these processes occur directly with the particle or if the particle dissolves to give ions and the ions are taken into an organism. This project will develop new nanoparticles which can distinguish directly between ion and nanoparticle bioavailability processes; once developed the nanoparticles will be used on environmental organisms such as shellfish to answer the question: is nanoparticle bioavailability controlled by particle or ion uptake? The outcome will be a better understanding of nano-bioavailability as a precursor to nanotoxicity.

This proposal will help to understand the mechanisms of bioavailability and bioaccumulation, as a precursor to toxicity; in particular, experimental and modelling studies will allow definitive answers to be generated on the question: is nanoparticle bioavailability controlled by particle specific uptake (and loss) or by ion uptake after dissolution. In addition, a set of tools will be produced, which will be disseminated to the research community, which will enable these questions of fundamental biological processes and hazard levels to be answered more broadly for a range or organisms and conditions. The proposed research will develop a library of novel particles, which are three layer core-shell materials, isotopically labelled with different stable isotopes in the core and outer shell, separated by an insoluble central layer. The tightly constrained and fully characterized nanoparticles will then be used as probes to perform scoping studies on model organisms to answer fundamental questions related particle or ion bioaccumulation. The relative importance of the ion and particle in biouptake and elimination mechanisms, in food and aquatic exposures and the importance of solution chemistry will also be investigated.

The developed nanoparticle (patent pending) and the study of toxicity feed directly into the development of a safe and sustainable industry, which will be of general societal benefit. Two doctoral students will be trained in interdisciplinary areas involving synthetic chemistry, metrology and toxicology. The students will be given experience in both academic and government laboratories. The outputs of the project will be incorporated into teaching performed at the Center for Environmental Nanoscience and Risk (CENR) and the students will help in this as a training exercise. The CENR employs a postdoctoral fellow to specifically aid in outreach and we will pursue specific dissemination measures to reach the public and the student body and inform them of the projects scientific and technological advances.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoparticles are small particles with novel properties. They are products of nanotechnology and are ubiquitous in the environment, due to their wide use in consumer products, industrial processes and elsewhere. They are incredibly important in modern society. Despite their many benefits, some, such as silver nanoparticles, can be toxic which means they may be a risk to the environment. Once in the environment, they may also be a hazard and risk to human because the nanoparticles might get into foods or drinking water. Ideally, the benefits of nanotechnology can be gained while reducing any hazard and risk.

To be harmful to health, the particles must get into or onto cells or organisms, which is related to a process called bioavailability. To make the question more complex, nanoparticles often change when in the environment. Freshwaters, estuaries and seawater contains salts, natural organic matter (NOM), suspended sediments and other materials and they are very complex. In these waters, nanoparticles change by a variety of processes (e.g., dissolution – similar to common salt dissolving in water; aggregation – individual nanoparticles grouping together to form clumps of particles of larger size; ripening - larger particles forming as smaller ones dissolve; corona formation – forming a ‘coating’ of NOM on the surface of the nanoparticle). All these processes affect environmental behavior including behavior related to bioavailability. For instance, aggregation might cause nanoparticles to grow and then sink under gravity. If they do aggregate, then organisms in sediments (oysters, mussels and others) might come into contact with the particles; if they do not aggregate, then the nanoparticles might stay in the water column and algae and fish living in the water (no at the sediment) might be affected.

In this project, we are interested in the form of the nanoparticles, particularly how nanoparticles dissolve to form smaller nanoparticles and dissolved ions. We are also interested in how this process affects bioavailability and similar processes, which occur before any toxic behavior. To study these processes, we developed a novel nanohybrid core-shell nanoparticle. The most sophisticated versions had three layers. The core and outer layer were isotopes of the same element (isotopes are the same element but with slightly different masses due to extra neutrons in the nucleus). The isotopes behave the same in the environment, but can be analyzed separately by a method called mass spectroscopy. The middle layer was an insulating layer, which was insoluble and prevented the core from dissolving. For instance, a nanohybrid type we used had silver (Ag) isotopes with a mass of 107 or 109, with a gold (Au) insulating layer (shortened to Ag107@Au@Ag109, where the Ag109 is the outer layer). We also added a final coating layer using polymers or small organic ions to stabilize them. We also had to make methodological developments, such as an improved way to analyze metals at very low levels in very complex systems.

In different experiments, we examined how these nanoparticles behaved in different types of environmental waters and laboratory waters used to test the toxicity of organisms in the environment. In addition, we looked at the form of the nanoparticle, which was taken into the cell or organism. Although we collected a lot of additional data, the main data was the ratios of Ag109/Ag107 or Au/Ag in relevant waters and in the cells/organisms. These ratios told us a lot about how the nanoparticles were taken up. One of the main conclusions for Ag was the behavior was very highly dependent on the nanoparticle concentration. All processes occurred at most concentrations, but dissolution was most important at very low concentrations and less important at higher concentrations. The processes were very dynamic and once dissolved other behavior occurred including the formation of new and smaller nanoparticles from the dissolved ions. Even at low added concentrations, only a small percentage of the original nanoparticles was taken into cells. In most cases, the dissolved ions were not taken into cells/organisms. Generally, either the original nanoparticles or secondary particles/complexes formed after dissolution were taken up. The processes were very different in different media and different organisms (oysters and algae were studied, mainly).

The nanohybrids give us a new tool to study these complex processes and the data collected allow a better understanding of the possible hazards and risks from nanotechnology. The science performed is important by itself. Pragmatically, the knowledge gained will help to develop an understanding of hazard and risk and therefore help develop the benefits of the technology while minimizing the risks.
